instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2877: What is 820-2877? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..
definitions.CHGR_DCIN: What is CHGR_DCIN? CHGR_DCIN comes directly from charger into ISL6258 or ISL6259, the resistor before it can be blown when there are surges. Should be checked when PPBUS_G3H is missing.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi I got this board a while back but hadn?t bothered to look at it. I?m just trying to learn these repairs and I?m sorry the majority of the boards are old. Anyway I replaced <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> one of the diodes was no good it had continuity in diode mode in both direction while the other side did not pin 3had 0 continuity to <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> so I ran a wire. I <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> had a short to ground on pin 16. Test pin 16 without <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> .469v Replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. No I have a green light on the charger and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is turning on every 30 seconds almost as if it?s sensing a current draw and shouting down.

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> = 16.59v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> = 4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL> =4.9v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_L</SIGNAL> =3.41v

<CHIP>U7200</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>5V3V3S5_REG3</SIGNAL>=
<SIGNAL>3V3S5_ENTRIP</SIGNAL>=

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> tries to appear?
Post basic voltages for <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, pins 16, 13, 3, 8, 17.
Post real voltage on pins 1 & 6 too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi yes I just rotated  <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and now I have good
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.56v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5v 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> =3.3v
tried power on pads and nothing the pad also has 3.42v
no s3 or s0 rails

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C7755</CAPACITOR> correct voltage present?
Post resistance to ground (ohm scale) at L6995; should be higher than 30K.

Check all RTC signals.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Will check other ?RTC? signals in a little bit

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SM_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> good?
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SM_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> =3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.4v
I?m having a hard time finding a point to check drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> one is un smc and the other is under cpu. I don?t see a test point or resistor to test from in between the two points.

<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> it doesn?t drop or even move

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Also <CAPACITOR>C2620</CAPACITOR> is not present and looks like it?s knocked off.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3R1V8_SO_MCP_IFP_VDD</SIGNAL> on pin 1 pin 2 is gnd

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> it doesn?t drop or even move"
Do you mean is always 3V, or just 0V?

<CAPACITOR>C2620</CAPACITOR> shouldn't be a reason for not starting, but I recommend you to solder it anyway.
Old platform, no way to measure <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>; sorry, didn't check that on schematic.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Sorry I meant it stay high at 3.4v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
These old machines get failing power button.
Check first if <RESISTOR>R5710</RESISTOR> is good.

Use <RESISTOR>R5014</RESISTOR>/15 and check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.
Be aware, MCP could be bad, after so many years.
You can try heating it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Shorted the point <RESISTOR>R5014</RESISTOR> got no pulse at I?ve got nothing at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> =0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
DC value looks good for that oscillation.
I suspect bad MCP; heat it for test...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b with fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I just found the issue :) it?s the <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR> that gave <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
so I wasn?t getting signal. It chimes I have video and I pop in a install dvd all is good so far. Thank you for your time :)

And thanks for feedback; it can help other people in the future...
